step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing Webcam not detected frequently during use
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Webcam not detected - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Error 0x74 on boot appeared after recent update
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Error 0x74 on boot - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows VPN cannot connect and then restarts
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: VPN cannot connect - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing Power supply failure frequently during use
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Power supply failure - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Headphones not detected appeared after recent update
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: My PC shows Disk 100% usage and then restarts
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Disk 100% usage - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get Monitor not recognized when using my PC
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: Ethernet link not detected - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL frequently during use
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Power supply failure - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Power supply failure - diagnostic suggests issue

step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.

step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.

log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Overheating shutdown - event logged in system

user_error_text: I get Webcam not detected when using my PC
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Webcam not detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing Resolution stuck at low frequently during use
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Resolution stuck at low - driver reported error

user_error_text: Update stuck at 0% - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Update stuck at 0% - driver reported error

step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: VPN cannot connect - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing Audio device not detected frequently during use
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: Audio device not detected - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get Bad sectors detected when using my PC
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Bad sectors detected - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: High CPU usage appeared after recent update
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: High CPU usage - driver reported error

user_error_text: Black screen on boot appeared after recent update
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Black screen on boot - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing Bluetooth audio not connecting frequently during use
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - driver reported error

user_error_text: Thermal throttling - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Thermal throttling - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing External drive not mounting frequently during use
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: External drive not mounting - kernel event recorded

symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.

log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Feature update cannot install - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT appeared after recent update
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows Error 0x74 on boot and then restarts
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Error 0x74 on boot - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows Screen flickering and then restarts
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.

step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: CHKDSK errors appeared after recent update
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: CHKDSK errors - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows VPN cannot connect and then restarts
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: VPN cannot connect - event logged in system

user_error_text: My PC shows NVMe not detected and then restarts
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: NVMe not detected - driver reported error

cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.

user_error_text: My PC shows Feature update cannot install and then restarts
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Feature update cannot install - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: GPU driver crash appeared after recent update
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: GPU driver crash - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows GPU driver crash and then restarts

user_error_text: Seeing External drive not mounting frequently during use
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: External drive not mounting - driver reported error

user_error_text: Distorted / crackling audio - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Distorted / crackling audio - event logged in system

user_error_text: Monitor not recognized appeared after recent update
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Monitor not recognized - event logged in system

user_error_text: I get Bluetooth audio not connecting when using my PC
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - driver reported error

user_error_text: My PC shows KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED and then restarts
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing UEFI not detecting drive frequently during use
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: UEFI not detecting drive - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows Partition table error and then restarts
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Partition table error - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows Disk 100% usage and then restarts
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing Bad sectors detected frequently during use
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Bad sectors detected - event logged in system

user_error_text: Slow internet - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: Slow internet - driver reported error

user_error_text: Headphones not detected appeared after recent update
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Headphones not detected - event logged in system

user_error_text: Drive shows as RAW appeared after recent update
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Drive shows as RAW - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing Screen flickering frequently during use
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Screen flickering - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: I get PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA when using my PC
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: I get SFC cannot repair files when using my PC
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: SFC cannot repair files - driver reported error

user_error_text: NVMe not detected - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: NVMe not detected - event logged in system

symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: NVMe not detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows Error 0x74 on boot and then restarts
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Error 0x74 on boot - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: No audio output appeared after recent update
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: No audio output - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT - event logged in system

user_error_text: Slow internet appeared after recent update
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: Slow internet - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Bad sectors detected appeared after recent update
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Bad sectors detected - driver reported error

user_error_text: GPU driver crash appeared after recent update
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Feature update cannot install - event logged in system

user_error_text: Drive shows as RAW appeared after recent update
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Drive shows as RAW - event logged in system

user_error_text: Feature update cannot install - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Feature update cannot install - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows Printer driver error and then restarts
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: Printer driver error - driver reported error

user_error_text: Ethernet link not detected - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: Ethernet link not detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing Bluetooth audio not connecting frequently during use
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - driver reported error

user_error_text: Keyboard not working - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: Seeing SMART reallocated sectors frequently during use
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: SMART reallocated sectors - driver reported error

user_error_text: My PC shows CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED and then restarts
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Automatic Repair loop appeared after recent update
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: Audio device not detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Artifacts / graphical corruption - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Artifacts / graphical corruption - event logged in system

user_error_text: Power supply failure - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Power supply failure - event logged in system

user_error_text: I get Overheating shutdown when using my PC
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Overheating shutdown - event logged in system

user_error_text: I get Ethernet link not detected when using my PC
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: Ethernet link not detected - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows Screen flickering and then restarts
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Screen flickering - event logged in system

user_error_text: Drive shows as RAW - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Drive shows as RAW - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing USB device not recognized frequently during use
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: USB device not recognized - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows High CPU usage and then restarts
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: High CPU usage - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Seeing Update stuck at 0% frequently during use
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Update stuck at 0% - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Bootmgr missing - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Bootmgr missing - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED appeared after recent update
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - kernel event recorded

step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - driver reported error

user_error_text: My PC shows SMART reallocated sectors and then restarts
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: SMART reallocated sectors - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows GPU driver crash and then restarts
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: GPU driver crash - event logged in system

user_error_text: My PC shows No audio output and then restarts
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: No audio output - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Thermal throttling appeared after recent update
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Thermal throttling - driver reported error

user_error_text: My PC shows Slow startup and then restarts
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Slow startup - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: I get DNS resolution failure when using my PC
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: DNS resolution failure - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing Screen flickering frequently during use
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Screen flickering - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Seeing Disk 100% usage frequently during use
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Disk 100% usage - driver reported error

user_error_text: My PC shows Windows update failed and then restarts
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Windows update failed - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED when using my PC
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - event logged in system

cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.

step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.

step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: I get UEFI not detecting drive when using my PC
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: UEFI not detecting drive - diagnostic suggests issue

symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Webcam not detected - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get NVMe not detected when using my PC
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: NVMe not detected - driver reported error

user_error_text: Partition table error appeared after recent update
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Partition table error - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing Webcam not detected frequently during use
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Webcam not detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows Touchpad disabled after update and then restarts
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: Touchpad disabled after update - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows Thermal throttling and then restarts
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Thermal throttling - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: VPN cannot connect - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: VPN cannot connect - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Microphone not working appeared after recent update
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Microphone not working - driver reported error

user_error_text: Black screen on boot - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Black screen on boot - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - driver reported error

user_error_text: Monitor not recognized appeared after recent update
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Monitor not recognized - driver reported error

user_error_text: Update stuck at 0% - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Update stuck at 0% - event logged in system

step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: No audio output - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing Bluetooth audio not connecting frequently during use
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - event logged in system

user_error_text: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED appeared after recent update
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: I get Monitor not recognized when using my PC
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Monitor not recognized - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Seeing Artifacts / graphical corruption frequently during use
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Artifacts / graphical corruption - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows UEFI not detecting drive and then restarts
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: UEFI not detecting drive - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows Power supply failure and then restarts
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Power supply failure - event logged in system

step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
