user_error_text: GPU driver crash - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: GPU driver crash - driver reported error

user_error_text: My PC shows Slow internet and then restarts
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: Slow internet - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Background apps causing lag - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System is slow, lagging, or unresponsive under normal use.
cause: Background apps, disk/CPU bottlenecks, insufficient RAM, or thermal throttling.
step_1: Open Task Manager to identify high CPU/Disk/Memory processes and close them.
step_2: Run disk cleanup and remove unnecessary startup apps.
step_3: Check for overheating; clean fans and ensure proper airflow.
step_4: Consider SSD upgrade or adding more RAM for sustained performance.
step_5: Run antivirus scan to rule out malware causing slowdowns.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: Drive shows as RAW - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Drive shows as RAW - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: My PC shows Update stuck at 0% and then restarts
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Update stuck at 0% - driver reported error

user_error_text: External drive not mounting appeared after recent update
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Performance & Slow PC: Background apps causing lag - event logged in system

user_error_text: Printer queue stuck - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Printer queue stuck - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: CHKDSK errors appeared after recent update
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: CHKDSK errors - driver reported error

user_error_text: Seeing Bootmgr missing frequently during use
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Bootmgr missing - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get Touchpad disabled after update when using my PC
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: Touchpad disabled after update - event logged in system

user_error_text: USB device not recognized appeared after recent update
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: USB device not recognized - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: DNS resolution failure - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: DNS resolution failure - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Bluetooth audio not connecting - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED appeared after recent update
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get Monitor not recognized when using my PC
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: Monitor not recognized - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get DISM restore health failure when using my PC
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: DISM restore health failure - event logged in system

user_error_text: I get SMART reallocated sectors when using my PC
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: SMART reallocated sectors - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: I get Windows update failed when using my PC
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Windows update failed - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Feature update cannot install - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Feature update cannot install - driver reported error

user_error_text: UEFI not detecting drive - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: UEFI not detecting drive - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Error 0x74 on boot - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Error 0x74 on boot - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing GPU driver crash frequently during use
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: GPU driver crash - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing Drive shows as RAW frequently during use
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Drive shows as RAW - driver reported error

user_error_text: Distorted / crackling audio - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Distorted / crackling audio - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Bluetooth audio not connecting appeared after recent update
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.

step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.

user_error_text: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT - driver reported error

symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.

step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.

step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: Webcam not detected appeared after recent update
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Webcam not detected - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing Overheating shutdown frequently during use
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: Overheating shutdown - event logged in system

user_error_text: My PC shows VPN cannot connect and then restarts
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: VPN cannot connect - diagnostic suggests issue

verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

user_error_text: Seeing Printer driver error frequently during use
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: Printer driver error - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get VPN cannot connect when using my PC
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: VPN cannot connect - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: I get SD card not readable when using my PC
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: SD card not readable - event logged in system

user_error_text: Seeing KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED frequently during use
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows UEFI not detecting drive and then restarts
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: UEFI not detecting drive - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: I get NVMe not detected when using my PC
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: NVMe not detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing SFC cannot repair files frequently during use
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: SFC cannot repair files - diagnostic suggests issue

cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.

step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).

symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.

verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: External drive not mounting - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: No display / No signal appeared after recent update
symptoms: Blank screen, flicker, artifacts, or wrong resolution.
cause: Loose cable, wrong input, faulty GPU or display settings.
step_1: Check cables and monitor input source; try another cable if available.
step_2: Test onboard video vs discrete GPU to identify adapter issues.
step_3: Update GPU drivers and reinstall if crashes occur after updates.
step_4: Reset BIOS and check for any display-related settings.
step_5: Test with another monitor to rule out panel failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Display / Graphics: No display / No signal - event logged in system

user_error_text: My PC shows Keyboard not working and then restarts
symptoms: External devices not recognized or not functioning correctly.
cause: Driver issues, faulty ports, or hardware incompatibility.
step_1: Try connecting the device to another USB port or system.
step_2: Reinstall device drivers and check manufacturer support pages.
step_3: Ensure device firmware is up to date if applicable.
step_4: Check power delivery for external drives (use powered hub if needed).
step_5: If device fails on multiple systems, consider replacement.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Peripherals & Other: Keyboard not working - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: Seeing Bluetooth audio not connecting frequently during use
symptoms: No sound, mic not detected, or distorted audio.
cause: Incorrect device selection, mute, driver issues, or hardware fault.
step_1: Select correct playback/input device from sound settings and test.
step_2: Restart Windows Audio services via services.msc.
step_3: Reinstall audio drivers from the manufacturer site.
step_4: Test with alternate headphones/microphone to isolate hardware.
step_5: Check microphone permissions in Privacy settings for apps.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Audio / Microphone: Bluetooth audio not connecting - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: Seeing USB device not recognized frequently during use
symptoms: Devices malfunctioning, device manager shows warnings or missing drivers.
cause: Driver corruption, incompatible drivers after updates, or missing firmware.
step_1: Open Device Manager and check for devices with yellow warning icons.
step_2: Download and install the latest drivers from the hardware vendor website.
step_3: Use DDU in Safe Mode for graphics driver issues to perform a clean install.
step_4: Roll back drivers if problem started after a recent update.
step_5: If device still fails, test on another system to isolate hardware vs driver.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Drivers & Device Errors: USB device not recognized - diagnostic suggests issue

user_error_text: My PC shows CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED and then restarts
symptoms: System crashes to blue screen with stop code; sudden reboot or shutdown.
cause: Faulty drivers, bad memory, or kernel-level issues.
step_1: Note the STOP code and reboot into Safe Mode to prevent auto-restart.
step_2: Run memory diagnostic (mdsched) to check RAM health.
step_3: Update or roll back recently installed drivers (esp. GPU/network).
step_4: Run SFC and DISM to repair corrupted system files.
step_5: If BSOD persists, test hardware (RAM/drive) or restore system image.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: BSOD: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - event logged in system

user_error_text: DNS resolution failure appeared after recent update
symptoms: No internet, slow speeds, or inability to reach certain sites.
cause: Router/modem issues, DNS problems, driver faults, or ISP outages.
step_1: Restart router and modem, and reboot your PC.
step_2: Run ipconfig /flushdns and then ipconfig /renew to refresh network settings.
step_3: Check if other devices on the same network have internet access.
step_4: Update network adapter drivers and disable/re-enable the adapter.
step_5: If VPN or proxy active, disable them temporarily and retest.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Network & Internet: DNS resolution failure - event logged in system

user_error_text: Bad sectors detected - system crashes with blue screen
symptoms: Drive inaccessible, errors when reading files, or system prompts to format.
cause: Bad sectors, corrupt filesystem, or failing disk controller.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive.
step_2: Run chkdsk /f /r on the affected drive to repair filesystem issues.
step_3: Check SMART status using disk utility tools for reallocated sectors.
step_4: If drive is RAW, attempt data recovery tools or professional recovery.
step_5: Replace the drive if SMART errors indicate impending failure.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Storage & Disk: Bad sectors detected - kernel event recorded

user_error_text: I get Automatic Repair loop when using my PC
symptoms: System fails to boot to Windows; error messages or repair loop.
cause: Bootloader corruption, disk errors, or incorrect BIOS settings.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct drive is selected.
step_2: Disconnect external devices and try booting again.
step_3: Use Windows Recovery → Startup Repair to attempt automatic fixes.
step_4: Run check disk: chkdsk /f on system drive from recovery command prompt.
step_5: If bootmgr missing, rebuild BCD using bootrec commands.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Boot & Startup: Automatic Repair loop - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get Windows update failed when using my PC
symptoms: Updates fail, system rolls back, or SFC/DISM report errors.
cause: Corrupted update cache, missing system files, or incompatible drivers.
step_1: Run Windows Update troubleshooter from Settings → Troubleshoot.
step_2: Clear SoftwareDistribution folder after stopping update services.
step_3: Run sfc /scannow and DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.
step_4: Manually download the failed KB update from Microsoft Catalog.
step_5: If feature update fails, use Media Creation Tool for repair/upgrade.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Windows Update / OS: Windows update failed - driver reported error

user_error_text: I get SMART reallocated sectors when using my PC
symptoms: Unexpected shutdowns, no POST, unusual noises, or device not detected.
cause: Failing components (PSU, drive, fan), loose connections, or thermal issues.
step_1: Power off and inspect internal cables and components for loose connections.
step_2: Check event logs and SMART reports for disk errors.
step_3: Monitor temperatures and clean dust from cooling components.
step_4: Swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units if possible.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, backup data and replace failing part.
verification: Confirm the system behaves normally (e.g., boots, sound plays, pages load).
log_snippet: Hardware Failure: SMART reallocated sectors - kernel event recorded
